svg.text: The Singleton Pattern restricts the instantiation of a class to a single instance and provides global access to that instance.
In PrintingHouseMS, this pattern ensures only one instance of critical system managers exists, providing
centralized control over printing operations, authentication, and configuration.
Prevents multiple instances of components that should only exist once
Provides a single access point to critical system services
Ensures consistent state across the printing house application
Centralizes management of shared resources like print queues and configurations
Prevents conflicts in printer assignments and job scheduling
Prevents external instantiation of critical system managers
Single shared instance stored as a private static field
Public method to access the instance (getInstance())
Ensures thread-safe instantiation in multi-user printing environment
Maintains consistent state for printing configurations, queues, and user sessions
Centralizes management of shared printing house resources
All print jobs are managed through a single queue manager
Single authentication service ensures consistent security policies
Prevents redundant instances of resource-intensive printing managers
Single configuration manager ensures uniform pricing across all orders
Prevents conflicts in printer assignments and job scheduling
Single point of control for all printing operations
Usage Example Scenario - Print Order Processing Flow
User login calls AuthenticationService.getInstance() for credential validation
Order processing calls ConfigurationManager.getInstance() to get pricing rules and paper types
New print job calls PrintQueueManager.getInstance() to add job to the printing queue
Queue manager uses the same instance to assign jobs to available printers
All system components use the same queue manager instance to track job progress
Pricing calculations use the same configuration manager instance for consistent rates
Multiple staff members access shared instances simultaneously for coordinated operations
All authentication requests go through the same AuthenticationService instance
Updates affect all users immediately through the shared ConfigurationManager
‚Ä¢ Manages printer settings, paper types, binding options, and pricing rules
‚Ä¢ Ensures consistent configuration across all printing operations
‚Ä¢ Controls print job queue and printer registry
‚Ä¢ Manages job scheduling and printer assignments
‚Ä¢ Handles user authentication and session management
‚Ä¢ LoggingService: Centralized logging for all printing operations
‚Ä¢ NotificationManager: Handles customer and staff notifications
‚Ä¢ ReportingEngine: Generates system-wide reports and analytics
PrintingHouseMS Singleton Pattern Implementation - Ensuring Single Instance Control
